H0.text: Democritus first developed the technology that, when improved, enabled Edwin Hubble in the 20th century to deduce that there are galaxies other than the Milky Way.

H1.text: Isaac Newton is the scientist who first developed the technology that Hubble's observations depended on to deduce that there are galaxies other than the Milky Way.

H2.text: Galileo Galilei is the scientist who first developed the technology that Hubble’s 20th‑century observations depended on, enabling him to deduce the existence of galaxies beyond the Milky Way.

H3.text: Anton Van Leeuwenhoek is the scientist who first developed the technology that, after improvements, enabled Edwin Hubble in the 20th century to deduce that there are galaxies other than the Milky Way.

A4.text: In 1609, Galileo was, along with Englishman Thomas Harriot and others, among the first to use a refracting telescope as an instrument to observe stars, planets or moons.

A5.text: Galileo's 1610 The Starry Messenger (Sidereus Nuncius) was the first scientific treatise to be published based on observations made through a telescope.
